name: Ambrosia artemisiifolia L.
gisdinfo: Ambrosia artemisiifolia is a summer annual herbaceous plant that is native to temperate North America in the United States and Canada. Also commonly known as ragweed this forb establishes easily in human impacted and disturbed areas in high abundance. It is considered an invasive species in Europe
column11: although it is not an extremely competitively aggressive species and is mainly considered a noxious weed that interferes with other cultivated crops. The main impact of this plant is the copious amount of pollen produced from male flowers that are allergens to sensitive people
column14: asthma and causing skin irritations.;  (herb); Common Names: ambroisie à feuille d'armoise
column70: Ambrosia artemisiifolia var. elatior f. villosa (Fernald & Griscom
column77: Ambrosia elatior L. var. heterophylla (Muhlenburg ex Willedenow

name: Centaurea maculosa
gisdinfo: Centaurea biebersteinii is a biennial or short-lived perennial composite and a very aggressive invader.  It has been reported to grow on a wide variety of habitats
column19: and timbered range. It is often associated with irrigation
column20: preferring areas of high available moisture. It appears best adapted to well-drained
column21: light- to coarse-textured soils that receive summer rainfall.  Seeds may germinate over a wide range of soil depths
column22: soil moisture content and temperatures. Dispersal is generally passive as seeds are shaken from drying capitula. Movement over greater distances requires transport by rodents
column25: or hay or commercial seed.;  (herb); Common Names: gefleckte Flockenblume
column27: spotted knapweed; Synonyms: Acosta maculosa auct. non Holub

name: Centaurea melitensis L.
gisdinfo: Centaurea melitensis is a herb of the family Asteraceae.  C. melitensis is native to Africa and Europe and was introduced to the United States. It is a highly competitive species that forms dense
column10: impenetrable stands that displaces native and desirable vegetation.  C. melitensis usually invades open
column11: disturbed sites and is often spread by humans and livestock via transportation of contaminated crop seed or hay.;  (herb); Common Names: Abremanos

name: Centaurea solstitialis L.
gisdinfo: Centaurea solstitialis is a winter annual that can form dense impenetrable stands that displace desirable vegetation in natural areas
column11: and other places. It is best adapted to open grasslands with deep
column12: well-drained soils and an annual precipitation range of 25 to 150cm per year. It is intolerant of shade. Although populations can occur at elevations as high as 2
column14: most large infestations are found below 1
column15: 500 m. Human activities are the primary mechanisms for the long distance movement of C. solstitialis seed. The short
column17: pappus bristles are covered with barbs that readily adhere to clothing
column19: and fur.  The movement of contaminated hay and uncertified seed are also important long distance transportation mechanisms. Wind disperses seeds over short distances.;  (herb); Common Names: geeldissel
column25: yellow star thistle; Synonyms: Leucantha solstitialis (L.) A.& D. Löve

name: Cirsium arvense (L.) Scop.
gisdinfo: Cirsium arvense is an herbaceous perennial in the Aster family. It occurs in nearly every upland herbaceous community within its range
column10: and is a particular threat in grassland communities and riparian habitats. C. arvense is shade intolerant and can tolerate soils with up to 2% salt content. It grows on all but waterlogged
column21: but not peat. It spreads primarily by vegetative means
column22: and secondarily by seed. The seeds spread as a contaminant in agricultural seeds in hay and in cattle and horse droppings and on farm machinery. It produces an abundance of bristly-plumed seeds that are easily dispersed by the wind and they may also be transported by water.;  (herb); Common Names: Californian thistle
column27: perennial thistle; Synonyms: Carduus arvensis (L.) Robson

name: Cynara cardunculus L.
gisdinfo: Artichoke thistle (Cynara cardunculus) is a large perennial herb native to the Mediterranean region of Europe. It grows rapidly and produces very deep roots
column10: and forms large rosettes up to 1 m or more in diameter. It has invaded Australia
column11: California and parts of South America where it is an aggressive weed
column13: massive monospecific stands to the exclusion of all other plant species.;  (herb); Common Names: alcachofa

Nymphoides peltata (S.G. Gmel.) Kuntze
gisdinfo: Nymphoides peltata is usually introduced as an aquatic ornament though it is not the case in its native area. However
column10: the sale and distribution of Nymphoides peltata is slowing becoming more controlled. It can become extremely invasive in shallow
column13: lakes and ponds. Currently there is little information available on the control of Nymphoides peltata but hand removal for small infestations and herbicides for larger infestations seem to be the most effective.;  (aquatic plant); Common Names: asaza
column18: yellow floatingheart; Synonyms: Limnanthemum peltatum Gmel.
